  25. I have been using Sonicare toothbrushes for many years. I don't really care about all the fancy features, just the basic toothbrush features. This has always included what they call Quad-Pacer. This simply breaks the 2 minute cycle into 30 second intervals which makes it easier to get the proper amount of time in each area of your mouth.<br /><br />I bought two of these which replace earlier &#34;Essence&#34; toothbrushes. I was very upset to learn that Sonicare has deleted the Quad-Pacer feature from this model. This is obviously some Marketing driven scheme to drive people to the higher priced, feature filled tooth brushes. I admit, I didn't study the list of features. That said, for them to remove a feature that has always been there is pretty poor customer relations.<br /><br />When these batteries no longer hold a charge I'll be looking at other brands.

  38. I got my first Philips Sonicare around 1995 and it finally gave out this year. I had replaced the toothbrush heads but the handle and recharger held up with no problems, ever. I ordered this replacement one and just love it and have no doubts it will last for years to come. One year after I started using my original Sonicare my gums became so healthy the dentist attendant took my previous x-rays and new ones all around the office to show everyone the astonishing difference in my gums and they were completely healed from gingivitis, also no cavities this time or since. I always had bleeding gums until Sonicare cleared up the gingivitis and I haven't had bleeding gums since. I will never use another toothbrush. Sonicare has proven it heals and keeps the gums healthy and keeps the cavities away. My teeth and gums always feel fresh and clean after brushing my teeth with my Sonicare. You can't go wrong with this product and especially if you have kids, get them started with the Sonicare to keep their gums and teeth healthy and fewer dental bills for mom and pop. A great product!

  60. Not my favorite. I think the one I received was faulty. It was very loud. Also heavier than new models if you are traveling<br />Amazon returned it no problem.
  61. This replaced a much older Sonicare that died after several years of intermittent use, and I find myself using this newer model almost all the time -- the shape of the brush head is less blocky, more diamond-y, and the stem is thinner and angled compared to the old model. I believe the old model was also the basic entry-level but it did have the 30-second beep reminder to get you to pace yourself while brushing, but that feature isn't on this new basic model. Charging base is more compact, and there is less plastic housing around the brush stem, so that means less to clean up but also less protection for the part that actually vibrates. If you're not worried about bumps and falls, then this model should work well enough.<br /><br />*Update: After a little over a month of daily use, this Sonicare toothbrush is behaving erratically -- the cycle does not reliably last 2 minutes but instead stops early, and the strength of the vibration has diminished. My previous Sonicare lasted for years, so having this new one sputter after such a short time reduces my confidence in Philips -- is there a quality control failure? I'm disappointed with the performance; if this was a kitchen appliance or shop tool, it would make me hesitate before buying this brand again.
  62. My last Sonicare toothbursh lasted for 13 years! I'm hoping this one will too. I appreciate the grip strips on this newer model. My old one had the quadrapacer (30 second interval timer) but I chose to skip that this time and save myself $30. Don't miss it at all. Maybe my old one was just tired, but this unit seems to vibrate at a faster pace (my husband even commented on the higher pitch sound it makes). The angled head and smaller brush does help reaching to the back of my mouth. The travel case is a nice little bonus, just wish is was big enough to tuck the charger in for travel longer than 2 weeks. I feel like this is a great price for a valuable product that should last years. I know I paid many times more for my first Sonicare and definitely got my money's worth out of it.
  63. Like most others, I’m quite happy with this product! I purchased the product after it was recommended by my dentist. The power of the Sonicare toothbrush is amazing. It cleans my teeth much better than other toothbrushes I’ve owned. The unit is rechargeable. Over time, I’m sure that the battery life will degrade; currently it lasts 2-3 weeks before it needs recharged. The detachable toothbrush head comes with a tightly fitting plastic cover for travel. However, I’ve found that steripods work better. The provided cover fits too tightly, so my toothbrush stays wet (gross!). Overall, I highly recommend this product (so does my dentist!).

The batteries started to die out on them though so the time had come to reorder and this was the &#34;newer&#34; version that was advertised on Amazon to replace the ones we had. They still work great and seem to do the job but my big complaint is that this model doesn't let you know to change quadrants in your mouth every thirty seconds like the older model did. It was so convenient to have that feature. Now I just guess when to change. It's never right but I think all my teeth get the same amount of coverage. I don't have a watch or a clock on the wall with a seconds hand so it was a bummer when that function disappeared. It's odd that the older version of a product is better then the current one, but this is the case for this sonic care model.

Check the base cavity each time you change out a brush and clean if necessary.

  175. works great. I had an old model that lasted 15 years. The negative comments about water contaminating the hand unit is no longer an issue. The tooth brush has a soft &#34;washer&#34; that seals the brush from the motorized unit. The newer size of the brush is far better than my old head. It is much easier to negotiate around my teeth. The only downside is that this unit doesn't give you a notice every 30 seconds like the old one did. For the price though ($40) this one couldn't be beat!
  176. This toothbrush has a completely closed design that makes it impossible for the internals to get wet or dirty. The trade-off of that is that the batteries aren't removable, and the charger is more complex than it should be. Though the toothbrush contains 2 AA batteries (glued into the unit), the time to a full charge is more than 24 hours. And unlike other modern electronics, this unit's input voltage is not international. That being said, the charger is inductive (no physical connection to the toothbrush) and it's very ergonomic. Just pick up the toothbrush, use it, then put it down and it will charge. You will need to get used to counting 30 seconds at a time, since this toothbrush really encourages you not to brush longer than two minutes.<br /><br />After using it, my teeth feel cleaner than they did with my previous toothbrush, which was the entry-level Oral-B Braun. I am happy with this toothbrush, despite the fact that Philips chose beauty over functionality at every point.
  177. I don't think I own anything else that is this old and still works. We now have two and I'm looking to buy another base because I'm tired of having to wait for my kids to finish with them. Never had any problems with either one, ever.
  178. Decent (and cheap) electric toothbrush ruined by awful, potentially harmful brush head design. The screw on dome style heads aren't water tight so water drips into the spacious cavity between the head and base, which is a breeding ground for bacteria and mold. Imagine my surprise when I went to replace the head after a couple months of usage and saw BLACK MOLD inside. I doubt anyone who isn't an obsessive germ freak is going to unscrew and clean the head and base after every usage. There are plenty of other similarly priced electric brushes (including those made by Sonicare) that don't have the problematic dome style head. Promptly threw this in the trash.

  231. This is my first review of any product here on amazon and although I have been a member for a long time I finally had to make a review on this product. First off let me start by adding that this products does what it is supposed to. Many people complain and rate it four stars because it does not beep after 30 seconds or have some kind of quarter minute timer. Secondly this toothbrush changed my life as far as how clean my teeth feel. I have brush for years using a conventional toothbrush and it always felt as if I still had a dirty mouth after cleaning. I have been using the tooth brush twice a day for two weeks now and my teeth have not only gotten noticeable whiter but they feel really clean. I also notice that I also notice that my gum sensitivity is no longer an issue as it cleans them very well and the increased brushing of the Philips sonicare HX5610 essence is a huge difference. I actually share one with my fiance and we just switch the brushes so that we don't need to charge two units. It works out great cause we save on power. I notice some people complain about build up inside the brush. The solution to this is after brushing your teeth and rinsing the brush I turn it on again so that the brush shakes off the water and dries quickly. Just my two cents. I definitely recommend this brush especially if you find you have a tough time getting a decent clean or your mouth and breath still feel dirty.
  232. It was not exactly what I was looking for. My old one had the quad timer. This one does not and nothing on it at the time I purchased it said it did not. It works fine otherwise. I guess at the time I need to move to the other areas when I brush.

One tip, when buying replacement heads do not get the generic replacements from CVS or other outlets; those are much louder on the vibration and the head doesn't seem to work as well or as comfortably; that's the best way I can describe it. The real replacements are expensive but worth it.

We purchased the \\"hassle free\\" packaging...don't know what that means, exactly, but the product wasn't encased in hard-to-get-into plastic. So, maybe that's it. Also, the this toothbrush comes with the little bag for traveling instead of a hard case like my older model does. In addition it is quieter than the older models. These are all bonuses. I do think that these toothbrushes make a difference; they keep you from brushing too hard and help you to brush for the recommended amount of time (2 minutes, I think).<br /><br />The only negative thing is that they can get kind of gross under the brush head. You have to clean them regularly. Also, the brush heads are kind of expensive. DON'T use the store brand that says it fits these...they don't fit well and rattle around. The brush heads come in two parts: the brush with the magnet on the end and the cap that attaches the brush to the motor/battery case. This second part doesn't wear out very fast and can be reused. I with Sonicare would have an (cheaper) option just to buy this brush part alone. Because of this extra expense and in my opinion waste, I docked a star.<br /><br />My husband begrudgingly uses it. I hope the dentist gives him a gold star during his next visit!

  260. I’ve been using Sonicare toothbrushes for many years and am a major fan. My latest one was a 4 year old Essence 5000 series and I recently smoked the charger while in Europe (I forgot it was not dual voltage). Instead of buying a new charger I decided to change to an EasyClean 500 series for the following reasons. The Essence has internal cavities in the brush heads that collect all kinds of nasty stuff. Even though I rinse it after every use, unmentionable things still grow there. It is virtually impossible to clean completely. Every month I would soak it in Clorox but even that did not always completely clean it. Also, this latest Essence model does not have Quadpacer. I consider this absolutely essential to proper use of the toothbrush. For these 2 reasons alone I strongly recommend that anyone considering a Sonicare toothbrush consider the EasyClean or other higher end models offered, even though they are more expensive. You will be much happier and will consider the extra $25 well spent. The EasyClean is the cheapest model that uses Proresults brush heads, which eliminate the problems encountered with the Essence series. Of lesser importance, the Proresults replacement brushes are cheaper and the chargers are dual voltage (100-240V). I gave the Essence 5600 3 stars for the cleanliness problem and the lack of Quadpacer. I would have given it 2 1/2 but that's not an option. If you read my review of the Easyclean you will see that I gave it 5 stars.

  319. I was a bit dismayed at the lineup of Sonicare brushes and having to make a good choice. After digesting 7-8 models, their features, prices, etc, I decided this cheaper unit would surely do the job. The bells and whistles of the higher end models sound great, but I came to the realization that I've been brushing with a good old fashion toothbrush my whole life, and this cheaper unit offers the advantage I'm looking for. It vibrates and cleans just as good as the units that are 5x as expensive! The modes of the other units (tongue cleaning, gum care, etc) are cool, but the reality is most people won't use those features.<br /><br />Pros:<br />- Definitely leaves my mouth feeling cleaner than my &#34;manual&#34; tooth brush.<br />- 2-minute timer makes me more conscious about giving my teeth and gums a good brushing.<br /><br />Cons:<br />- It would be nice to have the quadrant timer that pulses every 30 seconds so you know when to move to another section of your mouth. (if this model had the 30 second timer I would have given 5 stars)<br />- It isn't the sexiest looking unit. It's a bit larger/bulkier than the newer units, but not as bad as I thought it would be based on photos.<br /><br />The bottom line is this: if you're in the market for a Sonicare brush, buy this model! If you really love it and later decide you would in fact use the extra features of the more expensive models, then upgrade! The price on this is extremely reasonable, you can keep it as a backup if you upgrade, or pass the handle off to a family member (they can buy their own brush heads).

  356. I went looking for a high quality, no-frills electric toothbrush and the Sonicare HX5610/30 Essence turned out to be a great fit. The bottom line is that all electronic toothbrushes are superior to manual brushes, but I wanted to be sure I was getting a good one. The various brushes have pretty minuscule cleaning advantages/disadvantages, but I was able to find an academic article that made me more confident in choosing the Sonicare. Done at Northwestern Dental School, the study says that &#34;Overall, this study demonstrates that long-term use of these two electric toothbrushes improves periodontal health in adult periodontitis patients, and that the Sonicare brush is superior to the Braun [Oral-B] brush in reducing gingival inflammation and probing depth. Moreover, 6 months' use of Sonicare led to actual improvement in probing attachment levels of periodontal pockets.&#34; It's comforting to find academic support of Sonicare's superiority, rather than just a bunch of marketing hype.<br /><br />Pros<br />Academically supported by dentists<br />Good build quality--this brush has a weighty feel and a premium rubberized grip.<br />Two-minute timer--this feature ensures that I'm brushing for the proper length of time. I wasn't into the 30 seconds by 4 quadrant system that Oral-B uses since it seems overly complex.<br />Eases on the power--the brush is powerful, but it ramps up the speed over your first week to get your gums used to the new movement.<br />Sleek charging stand<br />Dishwasher safe--helps combat the mold issue discussed below<br />Low price<br /><br />Cons<br />The gunk/mold--this issue is real. I was careful in wiping it down the first week, but I got a little lax after that and quickly had gunk buildup around the brush head and on the charging base. To some extent this issue is universal to all brushes, but a gap where the brush head screws into the handle allows water to be trapped inside and get extra gross.<br /><br />Ultimately the pros outweigh the cons on this brush. It feels like a big step up in my oral hygiene for only ~$25. A little bit of maintenance to keep the gunk issue at bay and I'm satisfied with this brush. It even arrived with the battery charged!cons on this brush. It feels like a big step up in my oral hygiene for only ~$25. A little bit of maintenance to keep the gunk issue at bay and I'm satisfied with this brush. It even arrived with the battery charged!
  357. Sonicare is the best electric toothbrush. This one does not beep every 30 seconds to notify you that it is time to move on to the next quadrant of your mouth (and stop doing hamstring stretches on your left leg.) The 30 second timer is called a quadpacer or Quadtimer. This valuable feature is missing from this particular low end model.

  364. This toothbrush is my new favorite thing. It leaves my teeth so smooth and clean, it feels like I just left the dentist. At first I thought it would tickle too much but it really doesn't. It does take a minute to get used to the toothbrush doing the work and not you. It has a built in feature that allows you to &#34;get used&#34; to the vibration over the first 12 times you use it. (You can turn this feature off and on)<br /><br />The best part is this model is less expensive than the other models Sonicare offers and it works just as well (from what my friend who has the more expensive one has told me). It also has a timer that shuts off the toothbrush when you hit the recommended 2 minutes.<br /><br />I really would not ever go back to a manual toothbrush after using this. It really is that good.

  377. This toothbrush was recommended to me by my pervious dentist. To tell you the truth, I hated using it. I have always been using the Oral B toothbrush before going to the dentist who recommended this toothbrush. I was a heavy soda drinker & I loved sweets (I had a lot of cavities). The first time I went to this dentist, he suggested I switch from Oral B to this Sonicare Electric toothbrush, so I did. I have a severe gag reflex & every time I used this toothbrush I felt like I was going to be sick. The brush head was too big & every time I tried to brush in the back, I would always gag & I didn't feel like brushing my teeth anymore, which lead to Gingivitis. The brush head was so big & felt harsh to me. I prefer the smaller heads. I finally got tired of the whole experience & went back to the Oral B Electric toothbrush which worked out better. I just changed toothpaste & everything was fine. The Oral B toothbrush is very comfortable & it is not harsh. I cut out the soda & sweets & I haven't had a problem ever since. I wouldn't recommend this toothbrush if you have a serious gag reflex. This toothbrush might be great for a lot of people, but it wasn't the right toothbrush for me.

  393. My hygienist recommended getting a Sonicare, but they are much more costly than manual toothbrushes and I wasn't sure I would like them.<br /><br />So, I bought a cheap, battery operated electric toothbrush at a local store. I liked the feel of it, but after only a couple of months, it wouldn't turn on anymore. I thought it was just dead batteries at first, so I replaced them. Nothing. Another set of fresh batteries. Nothing.<br /><br />So I bought this lower-end Sonicare. I don't really need all the bells and whistles of the more expensive ones. And I LOVE the way this one works. It took some getting used to, and I hit my teeth with the hard part of the brush when I first tried, but it didn't take long to adapt. Also, it has a lower setting for the first several times of use, allowing someone new to this type of brush to get used to it. My teeth and mouth feel so clean after I use it.<br /><br />It is supposed to beep twice when it is in the lower speed mode, and once in the higher. Mine, after fully charged according to the light on the charger, didn't beep at all. I called customer service, and they said I needed to put the brush in the charger to see if it beeped. That worked, but since then, I can't get it to beep at all. Not a big deal, but still, not working quite as advertised.<br /><br />I chose this rechargeable one instead of the battery operated lower-end model because, with my cheap electric toothbrush I got first, I didn't like the feel when the batteries start losing power. Instead of just stopping, the brush just slowed and got less effective. I assumed that this would do the same but I don't know that for a fact.<br /><br />I do wish the replacement heads were not so expensive, but I found that they are pretty expensive for any of the better electric toothbrushes, so this one is not out of line with those. I'm willing to spend the extra money for the improvement in brushing.

  417. Once you've had a sonicare, you'll never feel like your teeth are clean without it.
  418. This product is a consumables profit play. The replacement brushes start to show wear in a week. They are completely done in 3 weeks. The cost of replacement brushes in bulk at Costco is about $6.50 each. Think about it. You spend $49 on the vibrator, battery and charger, but the real payoff for Phillips is the replacement brush. Fusion razor blade replacements, HP ink jet cartridges, and Sonicare replacement brush heads. This is where these companies make money. They design the consumables that wear out instantly, and gouge you on replacement cost.
  419. Toothbrush works well, but didn't realize it didn't have the 30 second &#34;beep&#34; to let me know that each quadrant of mouth was done. It just shuts off after 2 min. fMy old one had the 30 second beep feature and I liked that.

  584. This brush is a great buy. It is a fraction of the cost of other sonic brushes, and after using some of them previously I would buy this one again. Replacement brush heads are $8-10 each depending on quantity and location purchased, but they last 3-4 months. The off brand replacement heads don't fit as well and transfer some of the vibration into an annoying (and very loud) buzzing noise while in use. We went back to teh more expensive name brand replacement heads. Battery charge lasts for 2+ weeks so its possible to travel without taking the charger. All-in-all, love this toothbrush and have purchased for the entire family.

It makes no ecological sense to design a toothbrush so that much more than the actual brush that needs to be replaced (unless that is the business model to make money). We have succeeded in cleaning the brush by soaking in bleach and cleaning with a q-tip, but this has to be done every few weeks.<br /><br />We recently got a much better Dazzlepro from our dentist that has just a simple replaceable brush. We keep the Sonicare only as a spare or when one of us is travelling.

  596. My dentist recommended that I get this electric toothbrush -- and I was reluctant at first because of a bad past experience with a water-pik a number of years ago that caused my gums to bleed and that hurt a lot! I read the other reviews, and decided that since I'm not used to the 30-second alarm that some of the reviewers were quite fond of, I wouldn't miss it. I was more reluctant to spend money on something I wasn't sure I was going to like at all, so I got this &#34;basic&#34; model.<br /><br />I was happily surprised when I tried this device to find that it was not at all rough on my poor old gums, as I had feared (no bleeding, no soreness, no problems at all). In fact, the vibration starts out on a very gentle setting tit slowly (12 steps) gets a little bit stronger each time you use it, so you have lots of time to get used to it.<br /><br />I love this thing now! It really makes my teeth feel very clean.

  637. I received one of these as a Christmas present a few years ago. I was a bit skeptical at first. However, come late January or February, I had my first post-Sonicare teeth cleaning at the dentist. In just a month or so, the dental assistant cleaning my teeth said they looked much better. In six months, I go in for another cleaning. The dental assistant is so impressed that she says she is going to get one. In fact, she said she had receding gum lines and seeing how much mine had improved, she thought I just might have saved her teeth!<br /><br />Growing up, dental cleanings have always been painful for me. Another year, and two more teeth cleanings later and I can honestly say, it almost doesn't even hurt anymore...almost.<br /><br />Outside of them being pricey, I almost knocked off one star for one reason. These things do not seem to be real sanitary and are a bit hard to clean. You can clean them off under running water and they look all clean, but if you start looking in all the nooks and crannies, they get crud growing up in the head and down in the handle, and even in the battery charger (which isn't too hard to clean).<br /><br />I clean it off daily, but I keep a bottle of peroxide handy and hose it off with it every couple of days or so.<br /><br />Four stars? Five Stars? I figure when your dental assistant sees such an improvement that she goes out and buys one, and says \\"you may have just saved my teeth,\\" that's got to be five stars.
  638. THIS IS MY SECOND ONE. LOVE IT
  639. This is what I have come to expect from a Sonicare toohbush. Base is sturdy, Brush unscrews and comes apart for easy cleaning. I use this 2x a day and store the brush separately to air dry. Every few days pop the plastic sleeve to wipe down, although I have never found that to be necessary. Have never had any problems with mold or fungus as others have. Proper maintenance is the key to any possession. Good price, no unnecessary bells and whistles.

And even though I purchased it recently, it's already starting to break down. The charge light blinks all the time, running down the battery. This is obviously a second, or perhaps a fake from the folks in China. I called Sonicare, but SONICARE REFUSED TO HONOR THE WARRANTY. Phoned them four times for a replacement, and each time they gave me the runaround. Finally, I contacted Amazon.   653. I've always seen commercials regarding Sonicare toothbrushes but I figured it was the same as any $10 electric toothbrush that I could buy at any store... that was my thinking at least... and wow, was I wrong.<br /><br />The whole package includes a travel pack, the base/battery, the top/bristles, a plastic cover for the bristle area, and the recharge base.<br /><br />The toothbrush was charged out of the box so I could take it for a test drive immediately. The brush barely vibrates to the naked eye, but start brushing, and you'll immediately realize how strong it actually is. It also has a nice 2 minute shut off feature that let's you know that you've brushed enough... for some that would like to continue to brush, press that little green circle and brush on...<br /><br />I let the toothbrush sit without a recharging it, and I can proudly say that after brushing with it twice a day, it went for 6 days without a charge... that's a pretty good battery. With most devices that have a rechargeable battery, I would advise letting the whole thing die before recharging to converse the half-life of the battery. I always have my $10 electric toothbrush on standby for when my Sonicare toothbrush loses its power.<br /><br />Overall, I'm very satisfied with the purchase. I don't really have any negative to say about it.

  657. I have some gum disease and have even lost a tooth recently because of it. I felt the same problem coming on in another area of my mouth. I was so dreading the trip to the dentist, the inevitable tooth removal, and another hole in my head I do not need. In a last ditch effort to stave off the process, I did extensive research online and particularly here on Amazon. To save you my circuitous journey to this device, let me say I dumped the idea of the Waterpik, I tossed the through of the OralB electric toothbrush. I went with the Sonicare. The price here at Amazon is by far the best price I could find -- even with a 20% off coupon for Bed, Bath and Beyond.<br /><br />I bought the thing. It came super fast. I got it out and used it right a way. My teeth and gums were really hurting, puffy, red, bleeding...eh you know what I mean. Even flossing didn't help. So, once I put it in my mouth I was shocked at how serious that vibration was. It took a little getting used to. I knew it was good though. Right away I noticed my gums felt better. After a few days, the puffiness died down. The bleeding stopped after a couple weeks. And (knock on wood) as of now my gums have healed. Seriously healed. I love this toothbrush. I LOVE it.

  695. Briefly, for a lot less than half the price, the Essence offers the essential benefits of the higher-end Sonicare products and it should be a good buy for both existing Sonicare users who don't care about paying a premium for a higher end models' bells and whistles and for new/undecided users who would like to try out Sonicare without spending a lot in the process. I am very happy with the product and, despite it lacking some of the higher end models features (see below) the Essence is going to replace my current Sonicare brush.<br /><br />Background: my records show that I've been using a [[ASIN:B00008BFXG Philips Sonicare Advance 4100 Sonic Power Toothbrush]] since May, 2008 and I used a Sonicare toothbrush before that which should qualify me as both a 'loyal customer' and, hopefully, a knowledgeable reviewer for the Essence.<br /><br />The Essence shares some key features with most other Sonicare products:<br /><br />* VIBRATION METHOD - Cleaning takes place because the brush head vibrates hundreds of times per second. This usually results in 'love at first try' or immediate rejection. It was instant love for me but my wife simply can't stand the vibration and she will never use a Sonicare product so... try before you buy. Philips will allow you to return the product for a full refund if you are not fully satisfied with your purchase.<br />* REPLACEABLE HEADS - The most controversial aspect of Sonicare is the relatively pricey brush heads. They only last 3 months (4-6 months is possible but anything beyond that is not recommended) and they are not cheap whether you use a high end or a low end model.<br />* INDUCTIVE CHARGING - You simply drop your toothbrush into the charger's cradle and it will charge without having to plug it in and there are not metal parts making contact. This is very convenient and very high-tech looking.<br />* TWO-MINUTE TIMER - The Essence will stop running after 2 minutes which is the agreed-upon minimum time one should spend brushing teeth. Of course, you can start it again if the initial 2 minutes were not sufficient.<br />* CORD WRAP - Like most Sonicare models, this one has one at the bottom of the charger to store any excess cord.<br />* CARY CASE - The ESSENCE actually comes with a zippered pouch. It's better than nothing but not as protective as the Advance's solid plastic case.<br />* MANUAL - It's English only and it discussing proper brushing techniques, product features, maintenance and simple troubleshooting.<br />* 2 YEAR WARRANTY - on defects. Does not cover the brush heads, wear and tear, misuse or chips and scratches.<br /><br />And, these are the features that the Essence is missing when compared with the Advance which may or may not matter, depending on your needs. I am prefixing them with a '-' (minus).<br /><br />- QUADPACER - The Advance and other models give the user a signal every 30 seconds. This should help properly dividing brushing time between the 4 sections of your mouth (up/down, right/left).<br />- BATTERY CHARGE INDICATOR - Higher end models would show through a string of small LEDs the battery's charge level. A nice to have feature but can easily live without it.<br />- HARD CASE - see above. There is a soft one provided.<br /><br />Anyone who doesn't need the quadpacer feature could save some serious money by going with this less expensive model. When it comes to tooth-brushing, the Essence and the Advance perform very much the same. The Advance body is slightly slimmer and shorter but I'm comparing today's Essence with the Advance of over 4 years ago so they might be the same now.<br /><br />Overall, I am very pleased with both models but if I had to pick between the 'basic' Essence and the more feature-rich and a lot more expensive Advance today I'd definitely go with the more affordable Essence and use the savings to buy my a couple of years worth of brush heads.eth. Of course, you can start it again if the initial 2 minutes were not sufficient.<br />* CORD WRAP - Like most Sonicare models, this one has one at the bottom of the charger to store any excess cord.<br />* CARY CASE - The ESSENCE actually comes with a zippered pouch. It's better than nothing but not as protective as the Advance's solid plastic case.<br />* MANUAL - It's English only and it discussing proper brushing techniques, product features, maintenance and simple troubleshooting.<br />* 2 YEAR WARRANTY - on defects. Does not cover the brush heads, wear and tear, misuse or chips and scratches.<br /><br />And, these are the features that the Essence is missing when compared with the Advance which may or may not matter, depending on your needs. I am prefixing them with a '-' (minus).<br /><br />- QUADPACER - The Advance and other models give the user a signal every 30 seconds. This should help properly dividing brushing time between the 4 sections of your mouth (up/down, right/left).<br />- BATTERY CHARGE INDICATOR - Higher end models would show through a string of small LEDs the battery's charge level. A nice to have feature but can easily live without it.<br />- HARD CASE - see above. There is a soft one provided.<br /><br />Anyone who doesn't need the quadpacer feature could save some serious money by going with this less expensive model. When it comes to tooth-brushing, the Essence and the Advance perform very much the same.   791. Great electric toothbrush. If you're like me you consider brushing your teeth just something you do while your getting ready. This product is timed for 2 minutes of teeth brushing. Its very convenient because I used to just start brushing and walking around a bit. I know I now spend more time brushing my teeth and have found that there is much less scraping during my regular trips to the dentist.<br /><br />The first few uses took a little getting used to because of a funny tickling sensation but once you get used to it your good. I also find that I save more water since I shut it off while im brushing which is also good.<br /><br />One word of warning though, the rubber gasket between the brush and the mount to the battery handle can let water or other fluids get down in the little reservoir of the handle. If this happens and you don't know it, things can get funky in there so I'd keep an eye on it and check once a month to make sure its dry. I'd also remove the brush tips from the handle if your going to clean that rubber gasket at all.<br /><br />That being said I would highly recommend this product to anyone looking to improve their oral health in between cleanings and dental check ups, I've def seen a noticeable difference and will never go back to a standard tooth brush.

  834. I used a Sonicare years ago when I had braces and needed something to break up the gunk in between my brackets. I lost that brush a long time ago, and so when I heard they had a basic version for MUCH cheaper I didn't hesitate buying it.<br /><br />This toothbrush was awesome back then and is still the best toothbrush I've ever used. It blasts through all that plaque and buildup you get throughout the day. The first time I used it I was actually kinda grossed out at how much stuff had built up on my teeth. I went to the dentist regularly and brushed like they said, but apparently I wasn't brushing that well.<br /><br />The toothbrush times your brushing session as well: 2 minutes, just like the dentist tells you every time you visit. Just keep brushing until the brush turns itself off and you're done!<br /><br />The more expensive versions beep every 30 seconds to let you know when you should change surfaces (Top back to Top Front, etc.) so you'll just have to time it yourself with this model. It's not a major gripe, and I only miss the feature when I'm just waking up and am too groggy to count.<br /><br />My only issues with the brush are with the head and the charger. There is a gap between the brush head and the screw-top base that like to accumulate A TON of toothpaste and spit. There's really no way to avoid it, so I usually have to disassemble it and clean it every other day or so.<br /><br />The charger, while it works phenomenally at home, does not travel well. I take a lot of extended trips overseas and the charger is only rated to 110V. You'll need a voltage converter to use it in most other countries. The brush does have a 2 week battery life though, and I usually am able to stretch it that far with regular use. It does come with an easy to use carrying case, but the case doesn't carry the charger.<br /><br />For the price I wouldn't hesitate buying this brush again. Unless you have the money sitting around, there's really no need to drop the extra cash on a fancier Sonicare. You get the same experience for less!n a fancier Sonicare. You get the same experience for less!

  851. I remember these toothbrushes costing MUCH more than this! I'm very happy with it, and feel well on my way towards improved dental hygiene in 2014,
  852. I've owned a Sonicare for over 6 years. My first was an Essence e5000 I got for Christmas in 2008, a very early version of the E series. It still works after thousands of hours of use and charge cycles. I bought this one (sans the charger) on eB** because my old Sonicare wouldn't charge. I suspected the battery, but it turned out it's the charger, so a new one's on the way!<br /><br />This is the newer model of the e5000, the &#34;HX&#34; designation. The basic design is unchanged from the older model, but it has a different battery and some other welcome improvements from the E series.<br /><br />For those who don't know, the Sonicare is an electric toothbrush, but differs from other brushes in one major way. Instead of a mechanical system, it uses a sonic oscillator in the handle to vibrate magnets in screw-on brush head. The magnets are attached to rigid metal &#34;struts&#34; that provide counter pressure to oscillate the brush head and cause it to vibrate side to side 3000+ times per minute. The oscillations work to vibrate water molecules in your mouth that work between your teeth and gums to remove food, plaque and tartar many times better than a manual brush.<br /><br />The magnets never touch the handle, so there's no mechanical drive system. It's super simple and reliable, which I like. The handle and charger are permanently sealed and completely waterproof. The brush handle contains a rechargeable NiMh battery that lasts quite a long time. The older Essence has a NiCad battery that didn't give as much runtime. I found myself charging it once every 5-6 days with normal use. This one will definitely last longer, and hold a charge better. The battery won't get a &#34;memory&#34; as easily unlike NiCad cells, so it will stay functional longer. I only get about 2-3 days out of my old Sonciare now. It took all night to charge as well, so it's not a &#34;fast&#34; charger.<br /><br />To compliment the new battery, the toothbrush also has a new feature that gradually increases the intensity of the sonic action to help acclimate you to using it, as it takes a little bit to get used to the sonic action. It took me about 2 weeks to get used to the sensation and the vibrations. It also has a smart timer (the old one does too) that turns the brush off after 2 minutes to let you know you're done. It will also remind you when it's time to charge with a blinking light on the power button and a beeper that turns the brush off. You can continue using it, but eventually it will turn on then turn off after a second. The new design also has rubber strips on the side for control when your hands are wet. This is the most welcomed feature, as the old one would slip out of my hands occasionally when wet and slimy.<br /><br />The brush heads are disposable and really expensive (about $12 each, cheaper if you buy them in volume), but thankfully last a long time. Philips recommends replacing them every 2-3 months, but I've stretched mine out to a year with no problems. The heads are skinny and long, so you can reach way back into your mouth to get all your teeth. My wisdom teeth are in, and they don't need to come out, but it's critical to keep them clean and my Sonicare is able to do that.<br /><br />This is also affordable. It does the same thing as the more expensive Sonicares, sans some features for more than half the price.<br /><br />As far as function, it works great! I went almost 2-1/2 years without going to the dentist, and went I finally was able to go in, they said my teeth were spotless- no cavities- nearly no plaque buildup. Gums were perfectly healthy too. I credit it to the Sonicare. This won't replace flossing though, so make sure to floss before brushing (as recommended by my dentist).<br /><br />My only gripes for this, despite the improvements is the cost of the brush heads. Also, they seem to collect every manner of filth and goo that builds up on the inside. Gross. The handle is also bulkier and heavier. There's also a &#34;learning curve&#34; if you're a new user the sensation might be unbearable. Not a major detriment, but this may turn some off to it. My wife hates it.<br /><br />So...<br /><br />Pros<br /><br />Works great<br />Battery lasts a long time<br />Lasts a long time<br />New non-slip handle<br />Smart timer<br />Easy Start helps new users<br />Affordable<br /><br />Cons<br /><br />Brush handle is bulky<br />Heavy<br />Brush heads are expensive<br />Sonic action can turn some off<br /><br />This is a fantastic oral health tool. It simply works. Keeps me out of the dentist chair (except for cleanings). I have perfectly healthy teeth to testify (and a happy dentist). If you've been having dental problems, have implants or appliances, or want to take better care of your teeth, get one of these. It's not perfect, but you won't be disappointed.34;learning curve&#34; if you're a new user the sensation might be unbearable. Not a major detriment, but this may turn some off to it. My wife hates it.<br /><br />So...<br /><br />Pros<br /><br />Works great<br />Battery lasts a long time<br />Lasts a long time<br />New non-slip handle<br />Smart timer<br />Easy Start helps new users<br />Affordable<br /><br />Cons<br /><br />Brush handle is bulky<br />Heavy<br />Brush heads are expensive<br />Sonic action can turn some off<br /><br />This is a fantastic oral health tool. It simply works. Keeps me out of the dentist chair (except for cleanings). I have perfectly healthy teeth to testify (and a happy dentist). If you've been having dental problems, have implants or appliances, or want to take better care of your teeth, get one of these. It's not perfect, but you won't be disappointed.

Once the batteries are shot, you have to throw the toothbrush away. On line registration gets the warranty extended to 2.5 years, so I figure it will last at least three years. Even if it fails right out of warranty, having super clean teeth would bring me back for another Sonicare toothbrush.

  885. I owned a toothbrush like this about 10 years ago, but after several years of use by my husband and me, it eventually wore out and we didn’t replace it. In the meantime, I used manual toothbrushes and more recently, several battery-operated brushes. But nothing can compare to this Sonicare brush. It makes your teeth feel like you’ve just been to the hygienist, and with regular brushing (I brush my teeth twice a day), the Sonicare has removed a lot of the stains on my teeth that had built up while I used the other brushes. It’s is a bit pricey, but because I have gum disease and the above-mentioned stains, I went for the best, and I’m glad I did.

  906. The price on this for a Sonicare was too good to pass up. While it's a good value, there is a noticeable difference in how it operates compared to more expensive versions. This is the lowest end model that I've ever bought (I've own Sonicares for around 12 years now) and the velocity seems to be a lot less than other models. You may think that once you get past umpteen thousand strokes per minute, you might not notice, but you do. You definitely feel cleaner with the more expensive Sonicares.<br /><br />If you're on a tight budget and want a replacement for a manual toothbrush this is a good buy. However, if you're looking for something that cleans a lot better than a manual toothbrush, get one of the more pricier models. This is what I'll do next time.

  961. The toothbrush feels great on my teeth. There are a couple of changes I would love to see, however. My previous sonic toothbrush (from another manufacturer) had 30-second notifications while brushing. In other words, brush one quadrant for 30 seconds, then switch to the next, etc. It was a nice feature to have. The biggest problem I have with the Sonicare, though, is that when one reaches the 2-minute mark, instead of just pausing to indicate the 2-minute brushing period has finished, the toothbrush simply stops. If one prefers to keep brushing, it means turning the toothbrush on again. I prefer a notice that gives me the choice to keep brushing or not.

  1016. My old Sonicare toothbrush finally died after about 12 years of use. I bought this one to replace it and have been happy with it. With the new e-series brush heads I did have problems with water collecting inside. A few times I opened it and it was black and mildewy inside! Eeeeuww! But after reading other reviews, everyone said to take it apart once a week to clean it out and let it dry. I've been doing that and it's been fine. If you do that, you shouldn't have any problems with mildew forming inside. I hope I get another 12 years out of this model!

I don;t know what to do as I discarded all the packaging assuming it would be brilliant but it is unusable to me.
  1020. For the price you can't beat it. My teeth are feeling very clean! As other reviewers have said, the design allows water infiltration into the cavity between the brush head and the motor, that *could* allow for mold growth. However, a little preventative maintenance once and a while keeping it dry would stop this. Take it apart once a week, and dry it out! For 40 dollars you can't find a better tooth brush.

  1031. OMG, my head was practically spinning the first time I used this due to the intense vibration! I've looked high and low for the racing stripes on this thing but can't seem to find any. For me, this sensation is fun and enlivening, though I imagine it would be too intense for many people. My gums actually tickle when I use it, and the very first time, toothpaste splattered on my shirt and on the bathroom mirror. If you are elderly, disabled or a young child, this might not be the right choice for you. For me, however, all this power makes me feel like my teeth are getting really clean. My previous toothbrush was a Braun Electric Plaque Remover, which had a much gentler but still effective vibration. I'm enjoying the elongated, narrow brush head, which is similar to that of a standard toothbrush as opposed to the Braun's small rounded brush. The long, slender brush seems to allow me to gain better access to the harder-to-reach areas of my mouth.

  1062. Is this worth $40? You bet. HOWEVER, there is one major problem with this set which is why I gave it 3 stars rather than 5.<br /><br />This is Sonicare's most basic model, and, honestly, for most people this is all you're gonna need. The handle is a little bulkier than other models, but I don't find this a big deal. It also doesn't have the \\"beep\\" after every 30 seconds to tell you it's time to change the part of the mouth you're cleaning (you're supposed to use it 30 seconds each on the insides and outsides of the top/bottom of your teeth, resulting in quadrants that evenly space into the recommended 2 minutes of brushing), which I admit would be a handy feature, but it really doesn't matter. I more or less guess when it's time to move parts of my mouth and my teeth feel squeaky clean afterward. It's like a sandblast for your mouth.<br /><br />There IS the issue of wetness getting into the toothbrush and causing mold, but... uh, if you take the time to actually clean the toothbrush, this is NOT going to be an issue. Once you're done with your mouth, you can unscrew the brush head, and then easily separate the brush itself from the dome casing, and rinse both off. Then dry with a piece of tissue, and use the damp tissue to wipe out the inside of the handle. Then - and this is the rub - put it back in the charger but DON'T screw on the brush head until you're ready to use again. This allows air to circulate through the unit and you won't experience mold. Yes, it's a little bit of maintenance, but the whole thing takes less than 30 seconds. The instructions with the Sonicare say to do this every other week or so, but, really, it's not going to cramp your style to do it after each use and an ounce of prevention is a pound of cure.<br /><br />So, the toothbrush functions well, and if you care for it properly you're not going to have problems with cleanliness. I would recommend this model to anybody who's looking to really up their dental hygiene game and doesn't want todrop a mint on the more lux models.<br /><br />So, why three stars instead of five? IT ONLY WORKS WITH 110 VOLTAGE.<br /><br />I find this incredibly stupid. Sure, the charge on it will last about 2 weeks' worth of regular usage, but I work abroad regularly for periods longer than 2 weeks and need to be able to work with 220 volts. I have no idea why Sonicare doesn't make a 220 volt charger with this, or give it 220 volt charger capacity. The higher grade models allow for a wider range of voltage, so it's not as though the technology isn't there to make the brush able to function in countries other than the United States and Canada. This is particularly irritating to me, since I work abroad regularly and would like to be able to use my toothbrush.<br /><br />Essentially, I'm glad I got this unit at a mega discount (got some mad coupons before buying), since I won't be able to really use it for too long. I'm planning on giving this one to a relative and purchasing another model off ebay since I am not happy with the manufacturer for this and don't want to give them the satisfaction of buying a better model direct. I realize that I should have done a bit more research before buying (my fault); however, I think the fact that it ONLY works on certain voltages and you can't even use transformers to make up the difference is pretty heinous because it forces you to buy a model with more bells and whistles than you want, just for the ability to charge it in other countries.<br /><br />So if you travel abroad frequently, do NOT buy this model. If you stay in the US/Canada, there really isn't a need to go for the more expensive models as this one will do what you want it to do (clean your teeth) and is worth the full cost.

  1125. There are lots of gadgets on the market that are designed to automate day to day tasks, such as electric can openers and electric razors. These things may do what they're supposed to do, but they don't do much that you can't already do manually. The Phillips Sonicare toothbrush is not like that. It gets your teeth clean in a way that you simply never could do with a traditional toothbrush. It may clean even better than the cleaning you get at the dentists office, and it whitens teeth that you didn't even realize were stained. It doesn't abrade the gums. I can't say enough good things about this product; it is simply amazing. If you are on the fence about whether to buy one, don't hesitate. Buy one. I have never used any other electric toothbrush so I can't compare, but I doubt that any other type of electric toothbrush could be as good. One word of warning: the first 2-3 times you use it, the vibration tickles the inside of your mouth a bit and takes some getting used to. After the first few uses you no longer even notice it at all.
  1126. Great product. My original one finally died and this one was less expensive but works very well. So I'm happy.
  1127. Had an inexpensive electric brush to try which was loud. Now with this brand -is quiet&efficient.Good value.Will see at next dental exam if better results-I feel if will be yes.
  1128. This is my first electric brush. At first, &#34;yay!&#34;, its a nice step up. I have no major complaints except for the 2 minute timeout. I brush for 2.5-3 minutes and don't need a freaking nanny to tell me when to stop. I have to stop brushing, reposition my hand, press the power button, and then continue just to work around this.<br /><br />For a child, I could understand how it may encourage proper brushing time (BUT NOT TECHNIQUE!). But for an adult who knows how to brush their own teeth properly, FORCING a 2 MINUTE SHUTOFF is ludicrous and annoying enough to me to justify a one-star rating. They could have easily included a switch to toggle the behavior off.<br /><br />BTW, unscrew and regularly clean the cap if you get this. Otherwise mold will build up beneath - there's nothing like having a bunch of nasty black mold on your toothbrush.
  1129. This is my second Sonicare,my first being a higher end model-more features. This model is very basic, which is what I wanted. It fits the existing heads that I just purchased before my other one died, which I had for many years. Hopefully this model will last as well!

This little baby is charged up and ready to &#34;get the job done&#34; each morning when I grab for it. I just hope it endures (time-wise) like my OralB vitality toothbrush of 7 years did!
  1132. Previously, I owned an Oral B Sonic Complete electric toothbrush. I used it for approximately seven years until it slowly died, sometimes stopping short of its two-minute clean, sometimes not even able to start it at all. I finally gave in and looked up a new electric toothbrush to purchase, after all, who can go back to a plain old regular toothbrush after using an electric one? This Philips Sonicare popped up as the best seller/one of the highest ratings. I've now been using it for roughly a week. The brush head is a tad longer, and narrower than my previous one. I has a two-minute timer, but it does NOT have the 30-second intervals to remind you to switch to a new section to clean in your mouth. I'm giving this 4 stars because while it does clean my teeth quite well, I've noticed on a few occasions that it has made my gums bleed. Also, if my teeth slightly touch the back of the brush head while cleaning, it clatters quite a bit on my teeth. If, as they say, this is the &#34;gentler version&#34; during the first two weeks of use to prepare you for the real-deal mode of teeth cleaning, I am a bit nervous. I don't think my teeth/gums are sensitive, as I floss almost daily without bleeding gums. Nonetheless, it does the job and I am happy with this purchase.

  1168. UPDATE June 2015: I still love this brush, a caveat: Change the brush head much more often than you'd think - every 2 months - it works SOOOOO much better with a new brush!!! Also, swish (don't swallow) about a teaspoon of 3% H2O2 (peroxide) with your toothpaste for a ridiculous clean!<br /><br />This toothbrush is amazing! I'll just say this:<br /><br />With a manual brush, I notice a film of plaque reforming after 12 hours or so. I thought this was normal.<br />Well, imagine my surprise when after using the Sonicare, my teeth remained squeaky clean for 3 DAYS! Yes, I experimented to see how long I could go without accumulating plaque. This device cleans the mouth SO thoroughly, it's scary; the junk I spat out after the first use was truly frightening! All that bacteria that had been damaging my smile were dislodged with stunning completeness! The Sonicare literally vibrates the plaque out from under the gum-line!<br /><br />I sincerely wish you try this item for yourself. You will not be disappointed!<br /><br />BTW, in the case of travelling overseas - when fully charged, you'll get about 20 uses on a single charge...enough for a 10 day trip.<br /><br />A note about the design: I advise simply unscrewing the brush-head after every few uses and cleaning it with peroxide or just plain H2O. This will keep any gunk from accumulating inside the apparatus. It takes about 20 seconds to clean it, so it no big deal, IMO.<br /><br />This model is economically priced and functions flawlessly to give you a clean you thought only a trip to the dentist could give.<br /><br />If you find my review helpful, please give it an up-vote; I really appreciate your feedback!<br /><br />Thanks,<br />PeterThanks,<br />Peter

  1221. It's always a disappointment when a company tries to &#34;improve&#34; on what is already a rock-solid idea. This new version has a smaller head which I have yet to get used to. The brush head is a curved oval which also doesn't feel right and wears out much, much quicker than the old style. But the worst part is the floating head. It allows saliva and toothpaste to slip into a large empty space just above the magnets that cause the brush head to rotate. The new user is not aware of this and before you know it you have manufactured a breeding ground for bacteria. The entire space turned black and emitted a foul smell. It took me three days to clean it using hydrogen peroxide and blasting the interior with high pressure from my Water Pic. If you decide to buy one be aware that you M-U-S-T clean that portion of the head after E-A-C-H use with hot water. And once a week after the brush head is dry I irrigate the interior with hydrogen peroxide to keep that area from another bacterial build up. The Sonicare continues to provide me with healthy teeth but this new toothbrush is a major pain-in-the-butt!
  1222. I used to have an expensive Sonicare brush and wanted something cheaper with the same brushing power. The Essence did the trick. Just as much power as my old one and way cheaper.   1250. I think this was flawed, but I didn't send it back. My prior Sonicare paused every 30 seconds for a total of 2 minutes. This doesn't have a &#34;pause&#34; so unless you're watching the second hand on a clock, you don't know how much time you're spending brushing your teeth.

  1276. This model seems to be the current version of the original Sonicare brush we had 10-15 years ago. I loved it then because of how well it cleans your teeth. It is still way better for cleaning than a manual brush and even way better than the oral-B version, in my opinion. (I have had their version and went back to the Sonicare--it just didn't make my teeth feel as clean.) I have soaked these brush heads in rubbing alcohol, denture cleaner, put them through the dishwasher, rinsed them after each use and left off the motor so they would dry--nothing has worked. They do come clean (as far in as I can see...) but then they grow mold inside--again. I love Sonicare brushes but it is definitely worth it to upgrade to a model that uses the other style of brush head. I have had the HealthyWhite model for myself now (for the last 2 years) and never had a problem with those brush heads. I'm replacing the other ones our family uses with the higher level model. It seems a waste before the motor has worn out but I just can't believe this is healthy and personally think Sonicare should discontinue this model. Clearly they know it's a problem or they wouldn't have changed the design on the more expensive models.

  1364. After using this mechanical brush for several months, I can easily say I am never going back to a manual brush! By the way, this is the first mechanical brush I have owned so I can't compare it to others in this class<br /><br />Through using this brush, I have noticed (no placebo effect here) that a considerable amount of plaque has been removed. Seeing this really made me happy and my teeth were indeed more white. Using this brush does not damage nor cause your gums to bleed. If anything, it feels like a slight massage on the gums. Nothing harmful<br /><br />When you first use this brush, and if it's your first time using a battery-powered brush, you're going to feel a lot of noise in your mouth, traveling up to your head. This is normal and will subdue after a week of using the brush. At this point, I can't exactly recall what that feels like<br /><br />I read a few comments where people were complaining that this model brush did not feature the &#34;30 second beep&#34; interval, but a very simple way to counter that is just to use your smart phone as the timer. I do this every time I brush my teeth and the brush and timer are always spot on of each other. If you try to wing it without a proper timer, you might get an &#34;uneven&#34; sensation feel. It's best to get a timer and brush it that way so each quadrant gets an equal time.<br /><br />The travel bag, for me, is convenient when I sleep over relative houses and the bag is water resistant.<br /><br />The bad news is about this brush is the battery is sealed in the unit. Now, we all know batteries will die out sooner or later so once the battery can't hold a charge, you will need to think about replacing it (and recycling the battery). Depending on the battery, it could be a few years before this happens (I'm sure there is probably a clever way of opening this up and replacing the battery, but I imagine not everyone can be so crafty. If I see or figure out a way to do this, I'll possibly post an update on it). Philips recommends leaving the brush on the charger when it's not in use so I am going to assume the battery does not suffer from the &#34;memory effect&#34;, but I only charge it when the &#34;low-battery&#34; indication comes on, and for me, that's a week (sometimes I brush multiple times a day).<br /><br />I would also going on Philips site and downloading the user-manual for this. It has some good tips for using this brush that I can't remember right now.<br /><br />Overall, fantastic brush, and I can not go back to a manual brush again!). Philips recommends leaving the brush on the charger when it's not in use so I am going to assume the battery does not suffer from the &#34;memory effect&#34;, but I only charge it when the &#34;low-battery&#34; indication comes on, and for me, that's a week (sometimes I brush multiple times a day).<br /><br />I would also going on Philips site and downloading the user-manual for this. It has some good tips for using this brush that I can't remember right now.<br /><br />Overall, fantastic brush, and I can not go back to a manual brush again!

  1375. Our dentist has recommended the Sonicare product for years. Didn't really see the need. Finally purchased one and realized should have been using it for years. Purchased several more.
  1376. Sonic Toothbrushes are like washing-machines..The more you pay the more bells-n-whistles you get, whether you actually need/use them or not.<br />Here is the single benefit, to us, that we like; It DOES NOT stop vibrating the bristles and sound a buzzer 4-times every brushing &#34;cycle&#34;.<br />This brush just vibrates (with a not-to-loud hum mm).<br />The fancier brush models physically stop the motor and &#34;ding&#34;, to let you know they think it's time to move-on to another area of the mouth.<br />We did not want nor need that extra &#34;feature&#34;.<br /><br />As adults, we feel qualified to know when and where to move the brush.<br />It also cost less as a plane-jane model, but still doing the work of the $$ ones. We are aware that for the 2-minute &#34;recommended&#34; brushing time, some (also adults), prefer and seemingly enjoy the brush quitting, burping out a ding, and then continuing...as a reminder to move-da-brush.<br />Thus, a &#34;product line&#34;, and &#34;have it your way&#34;...That's good I think.<br /><br />In comparison to the older model Sonic with it's stubby fat toothbrush stem, we find this new longer-thinner brush-stem design a true improvement, as there is less plastic body to wrap you lips around. It's easier to keep your mouth/lips closed on the brush &#34;stem&#34; and thus make less of a mess while moving the brush around. With a little practice, and in fact NOT putting your head in the sink, we can brush the two minutes without dribbling.. try it!<br /><br />This brush, as in others similar, should have the nut unscrewed, and any unwanted junk/mold?, removed with a disinfectant, as under-the-nut is not truly waterproof. Another reason persons who prefer to not do this occasional clean-up, up-grade to the stated &#34;water-proof&#34; models. And only since Sonic has never &#34;fixed&#34; this model, to gasket-seal it, or provide a silicon slip-on sealing cover (which is available and good), we give it 4-stars.

  1384. Great toothbrush, cleans amazingly well, but the toothbrush is expensive, and the heads are expensive and unwieldy (seriously, you have to buy the whole screw-on part?). The well on the handle (underneath the screw cap that is attached to the head) traps water, which quickly turns into a yellow soup of bacterial growth. Yuck. Get the Sonicare Easy Clean instead (that toothbrush is even more expensive than this one, but at least you won't be growing a bacterial colony in your toothbrush...).

When I have to take a manual tooth brush when I travel it drives me crazy because I miss that extra clean feeling. This model is especially good. The main benefit to this kind of toothbrush is that I used to get about one cavity every two years or so, and I literally have not had a single one since I started using Sonicare. They also last a very long time - you just need to replace the brush heads.

  1398. I have owned this toothbrush for a little over a year. In the last 4 months, black mold spots have started to develop underneath where the toothbrush head snaps on. There is a rubberized-like seal here that makes mold prime for growth. Because of the gap between the toothbrush head and the handle, bacteria regularly gets trapped here. I have made a point to clean this area every month using intense hot water and dishsoap, then drying it. This has not prevented the mold growth. It smells horrible. I LOVED this toothbrush before this occurred, so please be wary of customers rating this before using it for an extended amount of time. I have gone and inspected the new models at stores and all but one model appears to have fixed this gap problem which leads to the trapping of bacteria there. This will clean your mouth, but it will not keep itself clean even when you diligently try to do so.
  1399. Excellent entry-level electric toothbrush. Makes my mouth feel very clean after using and the two minute timer is a nice perk.
  1400. It Is not as substantial as my old Philips Sonicare. I have been tempted to return it. It vibrates badly in my hand. I have to tighten it EVERY TIME I USE IT. Sometimes the brush part just starts wobbling so badly I have to stop brushing my teeth.

  1407. Ok, so I have to say I was legitimately impressed by this this electric toothbrush. I've had other cheap ones in the past and didn't really think that a Sonicare was worth spending the additional money on, but I admit now I was wrong. I think one of my favorite features, and it's the little things that count, is that it has an internal timer for the 2 minutes that you are supposed to brush your teeth for. So all you need do is press the power button and brush until it turns itself off.<br />My teeth also feel a lot cleaner with this brush. The vibration from it takes a little getting used to, but is well worth it for how clean it makes your teeth feel.<br />The other thing I really like about this toothbrush is the quality of the enclosure. My last electric toothbrushes all had battery compartments that you could unscrew and replace the batteries and so they tended to get water seeping around the battery. Here, the battery is completely enclosed with no real seams for water to leak in to or crack.<br />The only thing I don't recommend about this toothbrush is the replacement head price (~$30 USD), but it seems that coupons float around often enough to bring that down some. Otherwise, this was the best toothbrush purchase I've ever made.

  1469. I purchased the Philips Sonicare HX5610 based on personal recommendation from my dentist (and close friend). I have been undergoing a `rejuvenation' of sorts. In the past 6 months I've made it my goal (with the help of my dentist) to have the healthiest, cleanest and whitest smile possible in preparation for my best friend's wedding. The first step was to upgrade my toothbrush from my [[ASIN:B00763LZWQ old manual toothbrush]], to the Sonicare. I chose this because he said it was what he used at home, and it was somewhat economical compared to the other options he mentioned. This is also the reason why I chose [[ASIN:B00HJDIAGC this teeth whitening solution]] as opposed to using his services - he said it would cost me $500 dollars, then laughed and gave me the 2nd option!<br /><br />I am very happy that my dentist is an honest person who will recommend solutions to me not based on personal gain, but on quality. He said the way to use this product is as follows. You'll want to use this product for exactly 2 minutes, 30 seconds on each quadrant of your mouth. Think about your mouth's surface as having 4 sections, top front, top back (behind), bottom front, and bottom back. There is an easy 2 minute indicator that is built into this brush, which makes it easy to remember when you're done. Or you can simply watch a 2 minuteyoutube video, which is what I do to kill time while brushing! J (pro tip!)<br /><br />I was also worried about gum and teeth sensitivity due to how fast these things go. It's the equivalent to 31,000 brush strokes per minute. I asked my dentists about this, and he said don't worry about it too much, as long as you're not using a tooth-paste with heavy abrasive, because the combination of abrasive action and strokes can do more harm than good if used frequently and often. He recommended to only use a teeth-whitening toothpaste like [[ASIN:B004VGSVHS this one]] and a teeth whitening system like [[ASIN:B00HJDIAGC this one]] every-so-often to keep your mouth from becoming overly sensitive.
  1470. I have owned this model for several months and while it functions well, I only recently looked closely at the base of the brush head after removing it to clean it. I was shocked and disgusted to see that there is mold on the inside, which is hollow and inaccessible for purposes of cleaning. Some other reviewers have said removing the head and rinsing it after every use is 'no big deal', but that doesn't address the fact that the inside is a breeding ground for mold and bacteria, which could only be avoided, if at all, by making sure the inside 'pocket' dries out completely after every use. You would have to leave it unscrewed and reassemble it every day. This is a serious design flaw. I purchased this model based on the high ratings, but am now baffled as to how it got so many. I'm going to ask for a full refund from Philips. (On hold for customer service as I write this.)

Not horribly so, but a rubber back on the head might be nice. The head itself is a small profile and can reach everywhere. Two minutes can seem like a long time, but it's worth the smooth and shiny bright smile. The only thing that I found surprising is that the vibration causes me to salivate like Niagara Falls every time I use it. I use it about every third brushing. Don't forget to floss!

This is a low end handle, but I don't see a reason to spend extra money on bells and whistles. Functionally from the perspective of actually brushing your teeth, this is the same as more expensive models. I don't feel the need for a beep to tell me to move on to the next quadrant of my mouth or whatever. There are nicer looking models (Diamond Clean) and models with several features that I don't need, like settings for sensitive teeth and the like, which I also don't need. This one does the job for me.

  1621. Had the original model Sonicare for about 10 years and it always did a great job. Soon the batteries in that model were too weak to hold a charge long enough for travel even though it still worked adequately at home. When it finally died completely I sawed it open to remove the batteries and found that they were 1-1/2 volt NiCads (2 nickel cadmium batteries).<br /><br />The new Essex 5600 model advertises NiMh (nickel metal hydride) batteries inside. These batteries hold a charge much longer and don't have the &#34;memory&#34; problems of the old NiCads. My toothbrush now has renewed vigor and it will travel well.<br /><br />Weighing the difference between replacing just the handle and buying this new set I would have to say that the 2 year warranty, the new battery type (with matching charger) plus another brush head make the small difference in price well worth the money.
  1622. I had to buy a new one cause I moved away. They last forever, just get a new head every 6 months. Will pay for itself in dentist visits.

  1647. In the past few years I had my share of dental work done including an implant and a root canal. All those missed dentist visits resulted in a monstrous bill. The head is small and reaches areas normal brushes miss. The sonicare bristles are jagged shaped and cleans thoroughly. I also noticed some of the newer heads vibrate more and massage the gums. After using this for several months, I went to my dentist for my teeth cleaning and he commented on the excellent condition of my teeth (without knowing of my switch to an electronic toothbrush).   1684. I got this toothbrush about 8 months ago. I like it very much - my teeth feel so much cleaner than when I use a manual toothbrush. Sonicare is the company my dentist recommended. Two complaints: one is something that others have mentioned a lot - the way icky stuff builds up under the toothbrush head and smells; and the other is that it's not terribly durable. I've already had to replace it twice. Both times because of drops. The first time was kind of understandable - it fell onto a tile floor. The second time it dropped only 3 feet onto a carpeted surface. I suspect the battery connections are a weak point in the design. I think the maybe the way around both issues is to take the brush head off after each use, and lay both sides in the carrying case, laying flat. Also, despite the issues, sonicare stood by its products and replaced the toothbrush without question.<br />Overall, I would recommend this toothbrush. Just be aware of the issues, and if you have one, don't be shy to call sonicare customer service.

  1702. This toothbrush came in an easy to open packaging. It was easy to assemble, took me 2 minutes to put it together. The controls are easy to figure out. It does tingle in the beginning if it is your first time using a Sonic toothbrush, like it was mine. But, you dont even notice the sensation after a few days of use. It came with a full charge, but the instructions said to charge it for a few days continuously which I did. Now once charged, it lasts me a week of use twice a day. It gets teeth really clean without scrubbing.<br /><br />The no frills, 2 minute timer is very helpful. You can pause it and then resume the timer. You just have to gently move it over your teeth and it does all the work. Way, way better than battery operated drug store toothbrushes.

  1798. My husband and I have used Sonicare toothbrushes for many years. His dentist first recommended it to help with gum problems as well as plaque and general cleaning. A family can buy one unit and each use his or her own brush head, but we like the convenience of having our own separate units so we don't have to keep changing heads. I sometimes, ok most of the time, I wait longer than I should to visit the dentist but still have great check-ups. It will take stains right off your teeth and leaves the enamel intact. It works with internal magnets that somehow produce sonic waves rather than mechanical abrasion like manual toothbrushes and most electric brushes that I've seen. When I change the brush head, which isn't necessary all that often, I take the magnets out and and rinse them off. Those tiny little things make the most powerful refrigerator magnets you have ever seen in your life! No kidding! The Essence is rechargeable, so no batteries to change. You can use it for several days without charging if you want to take it on a short trip without the charging apparatus.This particular unit is one of the more reasonably priced. Sonicare does have some pretty pricey toothbrushes in it's line with bells and whistles that we don't necessarily need. This model works just great for us!
  1799. This is the third Sonicare toothbrush I have owned since 2005. Sonicare has been using cheaper battery components since I first used their electric toothbrushes. My first toothbrush took 6 years before it lost the capacity to fully charge a toothbrush. My second toothbrush, a year. This toothbrush lasted 1 month before I was unable to get a full charge capacity (Purchased December 11, 2012, lost capacity January 9, 2013). Granted, I paid slightly less for each iteration but if I can only get 1 minute of brushing it renders the purchase useless. For those looking to buy Phillips Sonicare toothbrushes, they've gone downhill since they started worrying about their bottom line. I know this will likely be my last toothbrush I buy from them until they can prove otherwise.
