  1864. I was introduced to Sonicare about 20 years ago. I fell in love instantly - in spite of the initial &#34;mouth full of hedge clippers&#34; feeling. I have used Sonicare exclusively since. My dentist has assured me that it has helped with my dental care tremendously. Last fall, I found that I could no longer get a brush head that fit the Sonicare model I owned, which was about 10 years old. The handle was perfectly functionally fine. But useless without brushes. So.....I had to get another one. And I somehow did not realise that the timer function did not exist.<br /><br />Is this sonicare good? Yes, just like other ones I have owned, it cleans wonderfully well. Does it have fancy trimmings? No, it is very basic.<br /><br />So basic that is lacks the timer that will let you know when it is time to shift the brush around (30 sec here, 30 sec there, etc) to get the full experience. I have been reduced to COUNTING in order to try to move the brush around properly. No timer in the bathroom. I have become so frustrated with this process that I plan to replace this perfectly functional toothbrush in the near future. Talk about a needless throw away! Now, twice, I will be getting rid of electronics that work just fine, except for small things like no more brushes or frustration with the lack of a timer. Personally, I feel that the timer is a significant and important part of Sonicare tooth care and not an extra trimming. Would be nice if Sonicare recognized that and fixed the problem.
  1865. Sonicare has changed my relationship with brushing my teeth. Before I bought this toothbrush, brushing my teeth was a bit of a chore, but now I actually look forward to how clean my teeth feel after brushing and wish I had a second one at my office to brush after lunch. I had an Oral B electric brush before, and I thought it was a good brush, and must be just as good as these Sonicare brushes, but now I know that I was just kidding myself.
  1866. Travels well. Good product. It made my gums healthier (or so says my dentist). Would recommend it to someone thinking about getting an electric toothbrush.
  1867. I love the way my teeth feel they have never felt cleaner and seems I use way less paste which I despise anyway good job for the money ended up getting deal and coupon love this tooth brush.

  1873. I ordered this to replace an older model that had died, and wanted something simple, for a one-person household. This model seemed to be the closest to my old one, and I have had good luck with it in the month since it arrived. It does not have the 30-sec. alert that it's time to change quadrant in your mouth, but I do just fine using my watch for that. I note that some other reviewers have complained about needing to clean the inside. I take mine apart every time I use it and rinse both parts with warm water. I purchased a test-tube brush (very small, at a dollar store) a few months ago, and about once a week, I clean inside the head using that brush. It keeps things very clean. I have had good dental check-ups since using Sonicare, which I started about 8 years ago. I recommend it highly - simple to use and each to keep charged. I keep the charger from my old unit in my travel bag and always have it when I am on a longer trip.

  1928. My wife and I each have one of these toothbrushes. One of them works perfectly. The other develops a gross black mold inside the top of the handle where it meets the brush head. This problem is so prevalent in these toothbrushes that a third party manufacturer has developed a product to remedy the issue. Search for Philips and black mold and the product pops up at the top of the list. It would seem that if the problem is in the design, Philips would just buy the company that solved the problem and put a water tight silicon cover over the brush and top of the handle.<br /><br />Basically, the toothbrush appears poorly designed. During and after you brush your teeth water, and who knows what else, gets inside the head because it is not adequately sealed against moisture. After a few weeks, you may notice that the surface of the charger develops a black crust on it. That is from the black mold draining out of a small port on the side at the top of the brush handle.<br /><br />Once the black mold is present, it is almost impossible to get rid of it because of the tiny crevices and hard to get to edges inside the handle.<br /><br />After spending a long time chatting with Philips and answering questions and given instructions not to put the unit in a dishwasher they agreed to ship me a new handle. They did not offer to send a replacement brush.<br /><br />When this unit becomes moldy, which it most likely will, I will toss it and look for a better product or start using the manual brushes that my dentist gives to me.
  1929. Vibration takes a little to get used to, but your teeth feel great after brushing! Highly recommend it. Bought one for everyone in the family!

  1937. If you are looking for the basic Sonicare, and you don't want to spend $119.00 this is a great choice. According to my Dentist and I have to agree, what this brush accomplishes: is 'disrupting' bacteria that cannot be gotten to sans the vibration that it creates. It is not possible to get to some areas under the gum line, but Sonicare manages to do so via the vibrations that are created when it is in use. Gum disease over time causes bone loss; which in turn causes loss of teeth. When you look at it like that, then it is well worth spending the money for a competent toothbrush.<br />Hope that helps someone.

  2044. The was the first sonicare I owned before I upgraded to the healthy white model. This is the cheapest one, but that doesn't mean that it lacks in cleaning power in any way. The vibrations took a little bit of getting used to, but after awhile, I actually started to like it. One thing I love it is the fact that after I was done brushing, it feels after-a-dentist-cleaning clean :) It gets the spaces inbetween your teeth and even under the gumline. It says on the box that you get better dental checkups, and that is the truth!<br />The only drawbacks to this model is the size and how the brush head is designed. The size is a little bulky compared to the other models, but it's not horrible. Also the brush head is a pretty big assembly that screws onto the top. Water and toothpaste can get under this assembly so you have to periodically take the top off and clean under the brush head and the place where it screws onto.<br />All-in-all, if you want a sonicare, but don't want to burn a huge hole in your wallet, this is a nice one to start out with.

I have moderate gum recession, and this toothbrush, unlike the Oral B, makes it worse--I constantly have pain when I brush, whereas with the Oral B I did not. Cleaning, however, is at least as good with the Oral B. We have been using them since the mid-1990s and I recall my dental hygienist's comment on my first check-up after using my Sonicare for six months. She asked, \\"Are you enjoying your Sonicare?\\" I said, \\"How do you know?\\" She said, \\"Sonicare's clean so thoroughly that it's easy for me to tell.\\" I highly recommend Sonicare and I bought this one as a gift. *Note: For first-time Sonicare users, the Quadrapacer feature helps train them to brush each quadrant of their teeth for 30 full seconds during the total two minute run time. It's not essential, but it's a good training tool because most manual brushers don't come even close to brushing for two minutes.

I washed my hands to go look into how to properly clean this and did not notice a bit of the gunk which was essentially a mold at that point was still on my finger/finger nail and I began to feel sudden pain as if needles were being punctured into my skin... After rinsing my hand in soap and and hot water for half an hour I'm here to report that I just threw the thing away and will be purchasing another electric toothbrush that won't end up killing me through mold grown inside of it. Jesus christ. Edit: Confirmed -- I received a finger nail infection from this product and will be taking further action with the manufacturer and Amazon to refund me completely.   2260. This was $29 after a $10 coupon I found on the site. For the money, it's the best thirty bucks I've spent in a long time.<br /><br />My teeth feel much cleaner, the buildup is completely gone and it's smooth as if I just went in for a cleaning.<br /><br />The unit itself is pretty big and the head does not pop off easy, so having multiple heads for each person in your house is optimistic at best (for the price, you can buy a unit for each person). The charger base is small and works well.<br /><br />I only have a few complaints: I wish there was a compact design. I charge this thing every minute except the 4 I'm using it, why does the battery need to be so big? I also wish the base would accommodate one more unit (not charging, just hold it). That way I could buy just another base and switch out when it needs to be charged. Also, a quick release top shouldn't be a \\"feature\\" of a higher priced model. Lastly, I should be able to switch out the brush at will, not the entire top. There's no way I should have to pay $10 per brush when only the tip has worn out.<br /><br />It's all still worth it. I'm buying another one for the wife and just setting it on the counter. Clean teeth are worth the costs.

  2265. Don't bother with this toothbrush. Spend a little more money and get the HealthyWhite or the HealthyWhite Platinum. I had a Sonicare Elite for almost 8 years and it was the best toothbrush I'd ever had. When it died, I bought the Sonicare Essence and I hate it. The handle is too thick and makes it hard to hold and maneuver. The on/off button is located so that it makes it easy to shut off in the middle of brushing your teeth. The Elite had the quadrant brushing had an alert every 30 seconds to shift brushing areas. The Essence doesn't and I had to count off every 30 seconds in my head in order to shift areas to brush. I used the Essence for about 3 months and then bought the HealthyWhite Platinum and am much happier with it. Sonicare makes a good product, just not this one.
  2266. I read other reviews before picking this product and was warned about the unit not staying charged so discussed this problem with my husband, an electronic technician and he informed me the toothbrush was not meant to stay on the unit all the time, just when it needed charging and that would make it stop working sooner so...as long as I just charge it every couple of days, until the light stops flashing...so far, so good!! Plus, the replaceable heads were not more expensive than the whole unit, like at the stores!

  2297. I've had one of these for probably about 7 years, had to buy a new one because the battery on my original one would't last two minutes anymore, it would die at about a minute and a half and switch off as soon as I pushed the button again. I bought the exact same model because it served my purposes wonderfully and it's a killer toothbrush. One thing I would recommend though, is unscrewing the brush from the base every couple days ( I unscrew mine every morning) to let the liquid inside dry out, otherwise you can develop a petri dish inside the internal workings. My medicine cabinet is made out of metal and since the feet on the brush part are magnetic I stick it to the side or top of my cabinet to let it dry out. Works perfectly. Brush heads should be changed about every three months, they can be pricey but if you live near a costco they sell them in a pack for cheap.

I was surprised at how loud the unit is when on, but that is a minor distraction. The unit really cleans your teeth and the brush bristles are real soft so you don't get bleeding gums. Even after drinking a cup of coffee, I run my tongue across my teeth and there is nothing, no food particles, no scum; just a clean feeling like you get after getting your teeth cleaned at the dentist. I noticed I have pockets and plaque build up on the upper molars so regular brushing always has my gums bleeding in this area even though I do floss. Since using the Sonicare, I have not had any issues. I hope this unit lasts as long if not longer than my OralB. I am glad I purchased this unit.

If you do not believe me about this product defect there is a whole line of products that they sell on Amazon to stop the mold for this tooth brush model. Of course Amazon is not to blame for this.   2434. Product itself works great. However, we've had this for less than a month and already it doesn't hold a charge. Initially, we would only plug it in the charger when it beeped and signaled low battery, which was about once a week. Lately, it beeps after one of us brushes our teeth. We then have to charge it all day, and at night when we go to brush our teeth, it is still blinking in the charger, whereas it previously would charge in less than 12 hours. Now we have to go through the process of returning it for a replacement. We both like how well the product works, but we're very reluctant to buy this again with an issue like this presenting itself less than a month after purchasing it. Update: This has got to be a joke. We returned the original toothbrush that was defective and Amazon shipped us a new one, which was great. Two months later, and this one is doing the same thing. Since two of us use this toothbrush, it should last one week on a full charge as opposed to two weeks if only one person were using it. In addition to the battery not holding charge, it occasionally doesn't even indicate that there is low battery. Earlier this week, I was brushing my teeth, and about one minute in, it just shut off. No blinking light, nothing. Just turned off. I thought maybe I accidentally pressed the power button so I pressed it again to make it turn on. It went on for a second or so and then turned off again. I contacted Philips and explained that this is the second defective toothbrush we've gone through in only a few months, and they said since I'm still under the two year warranty that they will send me a new one and I can return the broken one. What is wrong with this made in China junk? We take great care of the product? After brushing our teeth, we make sure to remove the toothbrush head and we clean it out gently with a piece of toilet paper so mold or gunk or whatever it is that people on here have claimed appears won't. We only charge it when it needs to be charged, which is when the light starts blinking. Per the manual, this should be two weeks on a full charge, but since both my wife and I use it, I would assume it should last one week. I would never buy this toothbrush again. It works great, and I love how effective it is, but the fact that two different toothbrushes have broken on us within a few months is just ridiculous.

  2597. The Sonicare HX5610 Essence has the well-known leakage problem -- saliva, toothpaste and water accumulate within the handle's chamber. This is due to the poor (nonexistent) seal from the rubber boot at the base of the brush stem. Consequently, fluids can leak out slowly down the handle, making it slippery.<br /><br />Strangely, this design flaw can be alleviated so simply with a rubber boot that fits tight around the brush stem.<br /><br />Recommend buying the Sonicare HX6511 Easy Clean, which is designed differently.

  2646. I have been using Sonicare electric toothbrushes for more than 10 years and like them for brushing my teeth and gums. Every model I have purchased including two of this model series has had a convenient feature whereby every 30 seconds the brush motor would pause and I would shift to another section of my mouth.<br /><br />Now some greedy executives at Phillips have decided to disable this function on some toothbrush submodels like this HX5610/30 so they can upcharge for it on their standard models. This is now called by Phillips &#34;quadpacer&#34; and you now need to pay extra for this basic functionality.<br /><br />Phillips also makes a recharging base that is 110v AC only, one that is sold in Europe that is 220v AC only, and one that is 110/220v AC which can be used anywhere in the world with only a plug adapter. I had to buy the 110/220v charger base directly from Phillips for an extra $45 plus shipping. Phillips should provide this dual voltage base as the standard charger or at least make it readily available through the same merchants that sell their toothbrushes.<br /><br />My next electric toothbrush will not be a Sonicare. I can pay less and get more with other brands which have gotten better reviews from testers.
  2647. This one replaces a similar model I had for over 10 years. I am able to use the brushes from the previous model.   2719. Everyone should have an electric toothbrush for superior dental care. This one is probably superior to most. The replacement brush-heads are grossly overpriced so I recommend taking a mini-hacksaw and removing the worn brush near the top from the elec toothbrush and one from a new regular toothbrush and epoxying (gluing) the new brush-head from the regular toothbrush onto the electric toothbrush shaft. Also, I had an older Sonicare that had died but I had kept the unused replacement brushheads. When I bought this model, it said that my older brushheads were compatible. But they weren't. Amazon lied. I had to use my hacksaw to remove the plastic tabs on the side of the old brushhead so it would fit in the new handle. Phillips is devious about making new models that are incompatible with older brushes. So the customer must get devious too with a hacksaw and glue.

  2806. This toothbrush came in the frustration free packaging. That packaging was a pleasure, and recycled very easily. I have been using the Sonicare toothbrushes for about five years, and had gotten used to the beep after every 30 seconds telling me to move to the next quarter of my mouth. This unit does not have that feature - It brushes for 2 minutes and then turns off. Now I need to use an external timer to tell me when to advance my brushing. This is not a major hardship, but it strikes me as being a silly marketing move on Philips' part. Otherwise, it is just what I expected, and it does a great job on the teeth.
  2807. I bought this toothbrush for myself just before the holidays.....and then someone bought me an Oral B that was twice as much for a gift. Feeling that I must follow the money...I put this one in reserve and switched to the Oral B. Now.....I am switching back. I just like the performance of this one far better. The vibration speed seems to be higher and it does a better job. Small pet peeve on both of them why such a bright d*mn light on the handle to indicate the charge level? I have to close my bathroom door to not see the blinking LED all night. I really don't need 24/7 streaming intel on the status of my toothbrush charge. Otherwise...quite high marks.

  2811. Recently purchased this device and I found it very useful for my teeth. It whitens (and brightens) my teeth in a couple of days of usage. The battery lasts long. The only problem I have is that it stops frequently right before I finish brushing; the timer of this electronic toothbrush needs improvement. This is a great product to buy at a cheap price compared to commercial battery-type brushes in the market.
  2812.   2813. the best toothbrush made! makes it effortless to feel clean every day! and my dentist likes it too!
  2814. This is my third one of these in 10 years. I fried out my first when I plugged it into a European socket. I replaced it immediately and it's lasted 8 years. It still works, but does not hold a charge for more than a couple days anymore. So I bought another one. Once you use this toothbrush, you won't ever go back to a &#34;manual&#34; toothbrush again. Get this: before I got the Sonicare, my dentist warned me not to brush so hard, as it was hastening the recession of my gums. After switching to the Sonicare, my gums are actually repairing themselves. I use the basic Sonicare: I don't need the bells and whistles of the higher priced models. Get one: you won't be disappointed!

  2824. I initially gave this Sonicare toothbrush 3 stars because my experience with it was rather ticklish, plus I found that \\"brushing\\" with it is kind of a hassle. With a typical non-motorized toothbrush I'm fond of wandering about when I brush. That's not recommended with this gizmo, since I've found it impossible to \\"brush\\" without foam dribbling down my chin<br /><br />Since then, I found that the ticklish sensation has gone away -- this was more attributable to the \\"learning phase\\" than anything else. Once the brush reached full speed it stopped feeling annoying.<br /><br />I have noticed that the Sonicare brush has kept tea stains down significantly -- which is why I purchased it -- so I'm quite happy about that. I still don't love the experience, but I do like it, especially the results! 4 stars!

  2830. Everything about this is wonderful. Can't recommend it highly enough. This is a replacement for another one I had for years - and which finally wore out. The only glitch: when you first buy it, the vibrator motor is turned way down for the first 14 uses (to get newbies' gums acclimated to it, I discovered). I thought there was some defect -- called their 800#...and a nice guy told me how to bypass that 14-day slow-vibration situation. (It is in the manual - small type somewhere ion pg 14 or something - but who reads all that stuff when it's just a toothbrush). They should point this out on page 2 perhaps.

I unscrew the brush head from the handle and wipe it down after every use.<br /><br />In retrospect, I would pay more for a brush that keeps everything the same but eliminates those two problems.
